Nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia can manifest with early adrenarche and can even result in CPP, but the normal 17-hydroxyprogesterone level in this patient makes this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Precocious puberty is more common in girls than boys, and the predominant etiology varies by sex. In girls, CPP is most commonly idiopathic, and CNS imaging is not recommended unless there are symptoms of neurologic involvement (headaches, macrocephaly, seizures, cognitive impairment, or visual impairment), concerning clinical features, or an especially young age of onset. In boys, an underlying CNS lesion is more common, so the workup should always include an MRI of the brain (with thin cuts through the pituitary gland) in addition to laboratory studies.

D) INCORRECT:

Exogenous androgen exposure can result in early development of pubic hair and early growth acceleration but would not be associated with testicular enlargement.

E) CORRECT:

This patient is experiencing early development of secondary sexual characteristics, including pubic hair, acne, body odor, and testicular enlargement (>3 mL). In addition, he has advanced bone age on radiographic screening.

Early puberty is defined in the United States as the occurrence of pubertal changes before age 8 in girls and age 9 in boys, although these thresholds may be somewhat arbitrary, given that the average age of pubertal onset varies across racial and ethnic groups and even within families. The degree of concern for early puberty may be especially heightened in those with a very young age of onset (as in this 6-year-old boy) and a rapid tempo of pubertal progression.

Early signs of puberty can be due to central precocious puberty, peripheral precocious puberty, or a benign pubertal variant.

• In central precocious puberty (CPP; also known as “true precocious puberty”), the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis is activated prematurely, leading to increased secretion of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). Although pubertal events occur early in CPP, they are appropriate for the child’s sex, and the sequence and timing of events is typically normal. Most cases of CPP are idiopathic in girls, especially after age 7. In boys, CPP is more likely to be caused by a central nervous system (CNS) lesion.
• In peripheral precocious puberty (PPP), there is excess production of estrogens or androgens, resulting in deviations from the normal sequence and timing of pubertal events. In some cases, the pubertal events may be inappropriate for the child’s sex, resulting in virilization of girls and feminization of boys. PPP has a wide range of causes.
• Benign pubertal variants include premature adrenarche (early signs of pubic hair without breast or testicular enlargement, growth acceleration, or bone-age advancement), premature thelarche (isolated breast maturation), and nonprogressive precocious puberty (initial signs of CPP but with slow or no progression over time).

Initial evaluation for precocious puberty should include early-morning measurement of LH using an ultrasensitive or pediatric assay, measurement of estradiol levels in girls or testosterone levels in boys, a bone-age radiograph, and measurement of an early-morning 17-hydroxyprogesterone level. In CPP, the LH and sex steroid levels are both elevated, whereas in PPP, the LH level is suppressed and the sex steroid level is elevated.

Key learning point: In patients with precocious puberty, clinicians must consider the possibility of a central nervous system lesion.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old girl presents for her annual physical. She has no significant medical history, takes no medications, and reports no concerns. During the past year, she has grown 4 cm in height and has gained 2 kg in body weight.
Her physical examination is unremarkable. Breast development is consistent with sexual maturity rating (SMR; Tanner stage) 3, and pubic hair is consistent with SMR 2. Her mother notes that her daughter began developing secondary sex characteristics about 9 months ago.
Which one of the following statements is most accurate to share with this patient?

choices.text: She can expect a growth spurt during the next 6 to 12 months
She will reach menarche in the next 6 months
She should undergo an evaluation today for delayed puberty
Her hemoglobin level will decline in the next year
She can expect axillary hair to develop in the next month

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Puberty in girls typically begins between the ages of 8 and 13. In most girls, breast tissue develops first (thelarche), followed shortly by the appearance of pubic hair (pubarche), but in a small subset of girls, the order is reversed. There may be a lag between breast and pubic hair development, as in this patient, which is normal. Although the timing of pubertal onset may vary, the sequence of events and progression through puberty is fairly predictable and consistent.

Girls experience their growth spurt after reaching sexual maturity rating (SMR; Tanner stage) 2 or 3. Before puberty, height velocity may decelerate slightly and then gradually increase as a result of sex hormone production. Sex hormones promote growth directly at the bone and indirectly by increasing production of growth hormone. Peak height velocity is achieved shortly before menarche.

This patient's development is consistent with SMR 2 to 3, and growth acceleration can be expected during the next 6 to 12 months. In girls, peak height velocity averages 8 to 9 cm per year. After menarche, girls continue to grow for another 1 to 2 years.

Key learning point: Girls typically achieve peak height velocity after they reach sexual maturity rating (SMR; Tanner stage) 2 or 3 for breast and pubic hair development — and shortly before they reach menarche, which typically occurs at SMR 4 or 5.

B) INCORRECT:

Menarche typically occurs at or after SMR 4 and is therefore unlikely to occur in this patient in the next 6 months.

C) INCORRECT:

Girls who have no signs of breast development by age 13 are considered to have delayed puberty. This patient’s puberty is progressing normally, so no evaluation is necessary at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Girls and boys both experience an increase in hemoglobin and erythrocyte mass during puberty, and they achieve adult hemoglobin levels by the end of puberty.

E) INCORRECT:

Axillary hair typically develops later in puberty, about 2 years after pubic hair appears. This patient, who began developing secondary sex characteristics about 9 months ago, is unlikely to develop axillary hair in the next month.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy presents for his annual examination. His parents note that he started developing pubic hair about 3 months ago and that he is the same height as his 9-year-old brother. He has no known exposure to testosterone creams or gels.
His vital signs are normal for his age. His growth curve shows a height of 132 cm (95th percentile), which represents an increase in height velocity from 5 cm per year to 7 cm per year since his last visit. His weight gain has been appropriate. He has pubic hair consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 2 and a testicular volume of 6 mL bilaterally. The rest of his examination is normal.
A determination of bone age is ordered; results are pending.
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Measure serum follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, and testosterone levels
Arrange for follow-up in 6 months to monitor growth velocity

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The presence of pubic hair, testicular enlargement, and increased height velocity in a 7-year-old boy is consistent with precocious puberty, which is defined as the occurrence of pubertal changes before age 9 in boys and before age 8 in girls.

Depending on the underlying pathology, precocious puberty can be classified as central (gonadotropin-dependent), peripheral (gonadotropin-independent), or benign (characterized by normal pubertal variants such as isolated breast or pubic hair development). This particular patient most likely has central precocious puberty, given the symmetrical testicular enlargement noted on examination. Although central precocious puberty is idiopathic 90% of the time in girls, it is frequently pathologic in boys and can be caused by tumors of the central nervous system (CNS). Thus, further evaluation is warranted.

Evaluation of precocious puberty begins with a detailed history and physical examination. A bone-age determination (already ordered in this patient) is important because children with precocious puberty tend to have advanced bone age. Laboratory studies should include measurement of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinizing hormone (LH), and either testosterone (in boys) or estradiol (in girls). The results of these studies can be used to distinguish central from peripheral precocious puberty, which then guides subsequent evaluation. An LH level >0.3 mIU/mL is considered to be consistent with central precocious puberty.

If the LH, FSH, and testosterone levels are found to be elevated and thus consistent with central precocious puberty, a brain MRI is indicated to further evaluate for CNS pathology (particularly given the risk for this pathology in boys). Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) stimulation testing is useful to confirm central pubertal activation. In the context of this test, a peak LH concentration >5.0 mIU/mL is diagnostic of central precocious puberty.

Key learning point: In addition to bone-age determination, the most appropriate initial diagnostic evaluation for a boy with precocious puberty is measurement of serum follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, and testosterone levels.

B) INCORRECT:

If the LH, FSH, and testosterone levels are found to be elevated and thus consistent with central precocious puberty, a brain MRI is indicated to further evaluate for CNS pathology (particularly given the risk for this pathology in boys). Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) stimulation testing is useful to confirm central pubertal activation. In the context of this test, a peak LH concentration >5.0 mIU/mL is diagnostic of central precocious puberty.

C) INCORRECT:

Besides gonadotropin activation, testosterone may be elevated due to other peripheral causes, including congenital adrenal hyperplasia and tumors, e.g., testicular tumors and human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)-secreting tumors. Asymmetric testes on examination would raise concern for a testicular tumor, and testicular ultrasound would be warranted in such a case. Obtaining an hCG level would help to identify the possible presence of an hCG-secreting tumor.

D) INCORRECT:

Nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency should be considered in patients with premature pubarche and accelerated growth or advanced bone age. The best test to screen for this condition is measurement of 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP) levels. However, this condition is not associated with testicular enlargement, as seen in this particular patient, and 17-OHP testing would therefore be secondary if indicated after initial bone age, LH, FSH, and testosterone levels return.

E) INCORRECT:

Follow-up in 6 months without more immediate evaluation would not be appropriate in this patient, given that his presentation is consistent with central precocious puberty and he is at risk for CNS pathology.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presents with concerns about changes in his body. He reports that his testicles began growing 6 months ago and that he also has pubic hair and adult body odor. He has also grown significantly in the past year and is now the tallest student in his class. He is otherwise healthy, and a review of systems is negative. His mother reports that she experienced menarche at 10 years of age.
Physical examination shows testicular volumes of 8 mL bilaterally and pubic hair consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 2. The patient’s growth chart is shown (figure). A bone-age radiograph is read as 12 years.
Which one of the following hormones is the primary cause of the difference between this patient’s chronologic age and his bone age?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although thyroxine also acts on the growth plate, this patient does not have signs of hyperthyroidism, and thyroxine would not cause an advanced bone age in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

In both boys and girls, estrogen causes skeletal maturation and epiphyseal fusion — and is the primary hormone to cause growth acceleration during puberty. Estrogen acts primarily by activating the growth hormone and insulin-like growth factor 1 axis, although it also has direct effects on the growth plate. Testosterone is converted to estrogen by the enzyme aromatase and also has a small, direct effect on the growth plate, but estrogen is the primary driver of skeletal maturation.

C) INCORRECT:

Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate is an androgen that may have some effects on growth-plate advancement and is often mildly elevated in premature adrenarche. This hormone is not the primary factor in bone-age maturation.

D) INCORRECT:

Progesterone does not have direct effects on the growth plate.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has precocious puberty, which is defined in boys as testicular growth before 9 years of age and in girls as breast development before 8 years of age. Precocious puberty can be caused by central or peripheral mechanisms. In contrast to peripheral precocious puberty, central precocious puberty is characterized by early activation of pulsatile gonadotropin-releasing hormone secretion leading to elevated levels of luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone, which then stimulate testosterone production from testicles or estrogen production from ovaries. The testosterone and estrogen then lead to early development of secondary sexual characteristics.

Patients with precocious puberty often have growth acceleration related to an early pubertal growth spurt. In both boys and girls, estrogen causes skeletal maturation and epiphyseal fusion — and is the primary hormone to cause growth acceleration during puberty. Estrogen acts primarily by activating the growth hormone and insulin-like growth factor 1 axis, although it also has direct effects on the growth plate. Testosterone is converted to estrogen by the enzyme aromatase and also has a small, direct effect on the growth plate, but estrogen is the primary driver of skeletal maturation.

A bone-age radiograph (typically of the left hand) is the best way to assess the degree of skeletal advancement, by evaluating the maturity of the growth plates of the carpals, metacarpals, and phalanges. More-advanced growth plates correspond to older bone ages; therefore, a patient with precocious puberty (who has had early estrogen exposure) typically has a bone age that is older than his or her chronologic age. Together with current height, bone age can be used to calculate predicted adult height. Individuals with precocious puberty are often taller than their peers in childhood but have short stature as adults because of early growth cessation as a result of early epiphyseal fusion. Clinicians can use bone age and predicted adult height to determine whether the predicted height is substantially below the normal range for adults and to help guide treatment decisions.

Key learning point: The hormone that contributes most to bone-age advancement in a child with precocious puberty is estrogen.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl presents for a well-child check. Her parents report that she has had adult body odor for the past year and pubic hair for the past 6 months. She is otherwise healthy, and a review of systems is negative. Her growth chart shows her weight at the 95th percentile and her height at the 90th percentile, without recent growth acceleration.
On physical examination, breast development is consistent with sexual maturity rating (SMR; Tanner stage) 1 and pubic hair with SMR 2. There is scant axillary hair and no clitoromegaly.
Her bone age is estimated at 8 years, 6 months.
In addition to testosterone and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, which one of the following laboratory markers will best aid in the diagnosis of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level that is related to severe primary hypothyroidism can lead to early development of vaginal bleeding, stemming from cross-reactivity with the follicle-stimulating hormone receptors. Elevated TSH levels are not associated with premature adrenarche.

B) INCORRECT:

Luteinizing hormone is an important laboratory marker for evaluating true precocious puberty (which is characterized by early breast development in girls and early testicular enlargement in boys), but this hormone is not necessary to measure in a patient with premature adrenarche.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia can lead to irregular menses and galactorrhea but is not associated with premature adrenarche.

D) CORRECT:

This patient is exhibiting signs of premature adrenarche, which is characterized in girls as the development of pubic hair and adult body odor before age 8 without accompanying breast development (and in boys as the development of adult body odor, pubic hair, or axillary hair before age 9 without accompanying testicular development). Advanced bone age is often seen in various forms of early adrenarche and puberty but is a nonspecific finding.

The differential diagnosis for premature adrenarche includes nonclassic (late-onset) congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), a virilizing tumor, exogenous hormone exposure, idiopathic (or benign) premature adrenarche, and central precocious puberty. Complete deficiencies in certain adrenal enzymes cause classic CAH, and partial deficiencies in the same enzymes cause nonclassic CAH. Defects in the 21-hydroxylase activity of the adrenal gland are the most common cause of both classic and nonclassic CAH, so it is important to rule these out. Girls with nonclassic CAH do not exhibit virilization at birth and are typically diagnosed during one of three time periods: (1) during childhood, after presenting with premature adrenarche (with or without clitoromegaly); (2) during adolescence, after presenting with irregular menstrual cycles and hirsutism; or (3) during adulthood, after presenting with infertility.

The best initial laboratory marker for evaluation of suspected nonclassic CAH is 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP). The blood sample should be obtained early in the morning because of the diurnal rhythm of the adrenal gland: Hormone levels peak in the morning and then decline throughout the day. If the morning 17-OHP level is elevated, further evaluation with an adrenocorticotropic hormone stimulation test is warranted for diagnosis of nonclassic CAH.

Additional androgen levels (testosterone and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate) should also be measured as part of the initial evaluation of premature adrenarche, to evaluate for virilizing tumors. If the evaluation is unrevealing and the patient has had no exogenous hormone exposure, idiopathic (or benign) premature adrenarche is the most likely cause.

Key learning point: The most appropriate hormone levels to measure in a patient with premature adrenarche are 17-hydroxyprogesterone, testosterone, and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate.

E) INCORRECT:

Estradiol is an important laboratory marker for evaluating true precocious puberty (which is characterized by early breast development in girls and early testicular enlargement in boys), but this hormone is not necessary to measure in a patient with premature adrenarche.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old previously healthy girl presents to the office with irregular menstrual cycles. She reached menarche 18 months ago. Her cycles onset “randomly” every 35–60 days and last for 6–7 days. She generally uses 5 pads or tampons per day and has never bled through to her clothes or bedsheets. The irregularity doesn’t bother her, and she denies any significant premenstrual symptoms or pelvic pain; her mother just wants to make sure nothing is wrong.
The patient has never been sexually active. She is on the cross-country team, running about 20 miles per week, and is excelling at the state level. She has never had any running-related injuries. Review of systems is negative for fatigue, appetite changes, headaches, visual problems, epistaxis, gingival bleeding, breast discharge, vomiting, abdominal pain, bowel or bladder problems, body image concerns, mood problems, and major stressors. She takes a multivitamin with iron every day. Family history is unremarkable.
Vital signs are normal. The patient’s body mass index is 20 kg/m2, which is similar to her past BMIs. A complete physical examination, including an external genitourinary exam, is notable for mild comedonal acne. Breasts are Tanner stage 5 and pubic hair is Tanner stage 5. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A complete blood count and thyroid-stimulating hormone level are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Refer to gynecology for an intrauterine device
Start a combined oral contraceptive pill

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine devices (IUDs) are commonly used to manage chronically irregular and/or heavy menstrual bleeding. However, this patient is not currently seeking contraception, is not concerned by the irregularity, and does not have excessive bleeding. In addition, in this high-level athlete, it would be helpful to monitor her menstrual cycles (without an IUD) as an indication of her underlying hormonal health.

B) CORRECT:

The typical age range for menarche is 10–16 years old. In adolescents, cycles usually occur every 21–45 days, last up to 7 days, and require 3–6 sanitary products each day. Abnormal menstrual bleeding encompasses any deviation from typical cycle regularity, frequency, duration, or bleeding volume.

During the first 1–3 years after menarche, anovulation due to immaturity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis is common and often causes irregular, prolonged, and heavy bleeding. Generally, the later the age of menarche, the longer it takes to establish ovulatory cycles. This patient’s primary problem is cycle irregularity. Typically, early anovulatory cycles occur every 21–45 days, but sometimes intervals are longer. Cycles more than 90 days apart are considered abnormal, and workup for secondary amenorrhea is required.

Anovulation due to immaturity of the HPG axis is a diagnosis of exclusion; thus, underlying medical causes of anovulation must be ruled out. These include pregnancy, polycystic ovary syndrome, thyroid disease, psychological stress, intense exercise, and eating disorders. In this case, pregnancy and thyroid disease have been ruled out on laboratory studies. As this patient does not have clinical signs of hyperandrogenism (e.g., significant acne, hirsutism) and she denies significant stress, observation and follow-up in 6 months is the most appropriate next step in management at this time.

Key learning point: In adolescent patients with irregular menstrual cycles who reached menarche within the past 1–3 years, if common medical causes of anovulation have been ruled out and the patient does not require treatment (e.g., for excessive bleeding or contraception), observation and follow-up in 6 months is appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) are commonly used to manage chronically irregular and/or heavy menstrual bleeding. However, this patient is not currently seeking contraception, is not concerned by the irregularity, and does not have excessive bleeding. In addition, in this high-level athlete, it would be helpful to monitor her menstrual cycles (without a COC) as an indication of her underlying hormonal health.

D) INCORRECT:

High-level athletes have an increased risk for eating disorders, and management involves reducing exercise intensity. This patient has a normal, steady BMI, and no bony injuries and therefore reducing exercise intensity would be inappropriate at this point.

E) INCORRECT:

Additional laboratory studies, such as a coagulation panel and ferritin, are not necessary because this patient does not have excessive bleeding or anemia.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother due to the new appearance of coarse hair in the pubic region over the past six months. She has no breast enlargement or body odor. Her height and weight percentiles have remained stable. Examination shows normal external genitalia without clitoromegaly. She has no acne or other signs of virilization.

Blood pressure
100/60 mm Hg

Which diagnosis best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An androgen-secreting tumor typically causes rapid virilization, including clitoromegaly, acne, and accelerated growth. The absence of these features, along with stable growth and normal external genitalia, argues against an androgen-secreting tumor. Such tumors usually result in marked androgen level elevations, which are not evident here.

B) INCORRECT:

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), particularly 21-hydroxylase deficiency, usually presents with virilization, such as clitoromegaly and accelerated growth. Electrolyte disturbances or blood pressure abnormalities may also occur. The isolated pubic hair development without these features, along with normal blood pressure and stable growth, is not consistent with CAH.

C) INCORRECT:

Central precocious puberty involves early activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, typically presenting with breast development in girls. The absence of breast enlargement, accelerated growth, or advanced bone age, along with normal external genitalia, suggests that the process is not centrally mediated. This presentation is inconsistent with central precocious puberty.

D) CORRECT:

Premature adrenarche manifests with the isolated development of pubic hair in young children without other signs of puberty, such as breast development or virilization. This condition results from early maturation of the adrenal zona reticularis, leading to increased secretion of weak androgens like dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and its sulfate. The absence of clitoromegaly, acne, or rapid growth, along with stable growth percentiles, indicates a benign process distinct from central puberty or adrenal pathology. This presentation aligns with premature adrenarche, where limited androgen exposure causes pubic hair development without other secondary sexual characteristics.

Key learning point: Premature adrenarche is characterized by early development of pubic or axillary hair due to early maturation of adrenal androgens, without other signs of puberty.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl presents to the clinic with irregular menstrual cycles for the past 10 months. She began menstruating at age 12, with cycles varying from 23 to 45 days. She reports no sexual activity, has no significant medical history, and denies medication use. Her BMI is at the 60th percentile. Physical examination shows normal secondary sexual characteristics and no abnormalities. Basic laboratory tests, including thyroid function and hemoglobin levels, are normal.
Which of the following best explains her irregular periods?

choices.text: Anovulatory cycles due to immature gonadotropin release

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In early adolescence, the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis is still maturing, leading to irregular gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion. This results in inconsistent levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), causing anovulatory cycles. Without ovulation, the corpus luteum does not form, leading to reduced progesterone production and irregular endometrial shedding. This explains the variability in cycle length, such as 23 to 45 days, commonly observed in adolescents as the axis matures.

Key learning point: Irregular menstrual bleeding in adolescents shortly after menarche is often due to ovulatory dysfunction caused by the immaturity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis.

B) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) involves ovulatory dysfunction and hyperandrogenism, often with obesity, hirsutism, and acne. In adolescents, irregular cycles can be normal due to hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis maturation. This 13-year-old has no signs of androgen excess or obesity, making PCOS unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Coagulopathies, such as von Willebrand disease, cause heavy and prolonged menstrual bleeding, not just irregular cycles. This patient has no signs of excessive bleeding, such as menorrhagia or easy bruising, and her hemoglobin level is normal.

D) INCORRECT:

Structural uterine abnormalities often present with primary amenorrhea, cyclic pelvic pain, or abnormal bleeding patterns. This patient has normal secondary sexual development and no pelvic pain, making a structural abnormality unlikely.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents with short stature and absence of pubertal changes. He is below the 3rd percentile in height, but his weight is proportionate. His father mentions a history of late puberty. Physical examination shows Tanner stage I genitalia and no abnormalities. Serum testosterone, LH, and FSH levels are in the low-normal range (see report).
Bone age assessment: Approximately 13 years
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Reassure the patient and family that growth will likely normalize

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exogenous growth hormone therapy is indicated for growth hormone deficiency, characterized by low growth velocity and very low insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) levels. This patient has a delayed bone age and family history of late puberty, suggesting constitutional delay of growth and puberty. Low-normal testosterone, LH, and FSH levels indicate a prepubertal state, not a growth hormone axis defect.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulsatile gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) therapy is used for intrinsic GnRH deficiency, such as Kallmann syndrome, characterized by low gonadotropin levels and absent puberty. This patient has low-normal testosterone, LH, and FSH levels, consistent with constitutional delay of growth and puberty, a temporary lag in hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis maturation. A family history of delayed puberty supports a benign process.

C) CORRECT:

Constitutional growth delay is characterized by delayed pubertal development and growth, which eventually normalize, resulting in appropriate adult height. This patient presents with short stature, absence of secondary sexual characteristics at 15 years, and a bone age of 13 years, consistent with this benign variant. A family history of late puberty supports the diagnosis. Low-normal testosterone, luteinizing hormone (LH), and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels indicate an intact hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, albeit delayed. Regular monitoring and reassurance are appropriate management strategies.

Key learning point: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty is a common cause of delayed puberty in adolescents, characterized by a temporary delay in skeletal growth and height, with eventual normal adult height.

D) INCORRECT:

Pituitary MRI is used to evaluate central causes of pubertal delay, such as intracranial lesions. This patient has a family history of late puberty and a slightly delayed bone age, suggesting constitutional delay of growth and puberty. Low-normal testosterone, LH, and FSH levels indicate a prepubertal hormonal state, not central hypogonadism. There are no neurological symptoms to suggest a pituitary lesion.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother for evaluation of breast and pubic hair development over the past 6 months. She reports no headaches or changes in vision. Examination shows Tanner stage 2 breast development, mild pubic hair, and advanced bone age. Her growth velocity is similar to that of a typical 9-year-old (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Luteinizing hormone
3.5 IU/L
1.0 - 1.6 IU/L


Follicle-stimulating hormone
4.0 IU/L
1.0 - 1.6 IU/L


Estradiol
15 pg/mL
Undetectable - 10 pg/mL (Prepubertal)



Which of the following processes most likely explains the pathophysiology behind her condition?

choices.text: Premature gonadotropin-releasing hormone release from the hypothalamus leading to increased gonadotropins
Ovarian estrogen production from an autonomous glandular mass
Adrenal androgen excess with peripheral estrogen conversion
Exogenous estrogen exposure prompting early secondary sexual characteristics

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Central precocious puberty involves early activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Premature, pulsatile secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus stimulates the anterior pituitary to release luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). These elevated gonadotropins promote estrogen production by the ovaries, leading to secondary sexual characteristics and advanced bone age. The elevated LH, FSH, and estradiol levels, along with Tanner stage 2 development, reflect this hormonal activation. In girls, central precocious puberty is often idiopathic.

Key learning point: Central precocious puberty is the most common cause of early puberty in girls and is due to early activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, leading to the development of secondary sexual characteristics before age 8.

B) INCORRECT:

An estrogen-secreting ovarian mass would cause high estrogen levels and suppress LH and FSH due to negative feedback. The elevated gonadotropin levels in this patient indicate activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, not an autonomous ovarian source. No clinical findings suggest a hormone-secreting ovarian tumor.

C) INCORRECT:

Adrenal androgen excess can cause early pubic hair development but not significant breast development. It typically results in suppressed gonadotropin levels due to negative feedback. The elevated LH and FSH levels in this patient suggest central activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, consistent with central precocious puberty.

D) INCORRECT:

Exogenous estrogen exposure increases circulating estrogen levels, suppressing gonadotropins due to negative feedback. The elevated LH and FSH levels in this patient indicate endogenous hormonal activation, not exogenous estrogen exposure. Advanced bone age and secondary sexual characteristics suggest central activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother due to concerns about breast development over the past three months. She has no headaches, vision changes, or other complaints. Her vital signs and growth parameters are normal for her age. An advanced bone age evaluation is pending. The mother wonders if her daughter is starting puberty too early.
Which of the following best explains this child's current pubertal status?

choices.text: Normal physiologic puberty for her age

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Late-onset congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) results from partial enzyme deficiency, leading to excess adrenal androgens and signs like early pubic hair, acne, and clitoromegaly. This 9-year-old's isolated breast development, driven by estrogen, lacks hyperandrogenic features, making CAH unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Central precocious puberty involves early activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, typically before age 8 in girls. This 9-year-old's breast development falls within the normal age range for puberty. Central precocious puberty often progresses rapidly and may include neurological signs if a central lesion is present, neither of which are observed here.

C) INCORRECT:

Estrogen-secreting ovarian tumors cause rapid peripheral precocious puberty, often with vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, or a palpable mass. This 9-year-old's gradual breast development and normal growth trajectory align with normal puberty, lacking additional symptoms indicative of a tumor.

D) CORRECT:

In girls, puberty typically begins between ages 8 and 13, with thelarche (breast budding) as the initial sign due to rising estrogen levels. An advanced bone age is common during normal puberty due to sex steroid influence on growth plates. This 9-year-old's breast development fits within the expected age range for normal puberty, distinguishing it from pathological conditions. Girls generally start puberty earlier than boys, who begin between ages 9 and 14.

Key learning point: Girls typically enter puberty 2-3 years earlier than boys, with girls starting between ages 8-13 and boys between ages 9-14.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy presents for a routine sports physical. He has no significant past medical history. Examination shows coarse and curly pubic hair covering the entire pubic area but not the medial thighs, darker scrotal skin, and a penis that has increased in breadth with development of the glans. Testicular volume is around 15 mL in each testicle. There is no axillary hair.
Which Tanner stage does this exam best represent?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Tanner stage IV in male pubertal development is characterized by testicular volumes of approximately 15–20 mL, consistent with the measurement provided. The penis enlarges in breadth, and the glans becomes more prominent, indicating continued maturation. Pubic hair becomes coarse and curly, covering most of the pubic region but not extending to the medial thighs, distinguishing it from the adult pattern seen in stage V. Additionally, scrotal skin darkens and becomes more rugose. These features align with Tanner stage IV, reflecting advanced but not complete pubertal development.

Key learning point: In Tanner stage IV of male puberty, pubic hair becomes adult-like in texture and distribution, and the scrotal skin darkens.

B) INCORRECT:

Tanner stage II is marked by initial testicular enlargement (4–6 mL) and sparse, lightly pigmented pubic hair at the scrotum or base of the penis. The described testicular volume of 15 mL and coarse, curly pubic hair covering the entire pubic area indicate a more advanced stage than stage II.

C) INCORRECT:

Tanner stage V features an adult distribution of pubic hair extending to the medial thighs and fully developed axillary hair. The absence of pubic hair on the medial thighs and a testicular volume of 15 mL indicate that full adult maturation has not been reached, ruling out stage V.

D) INCORRECT:

Tanner stage III involves testicular volumes generally lower than 15 mL and pubic hair that is coarser and curlier but not as extensive as described. The penile changes, including increased breadth and glans development, suggest a more advanced stage than stage III.

questions.text:
A 14-month-old girl is brought to the clinic by her grandmother due to mildly enlarged breasts persisting for 2 months. She has no axillary or pubic hair. Her height is at the 50th percentile for age. Her mother had normal timing of puberty. Physical examination confirms bilateral breast tissue with no other signs of sexual development. There is no vaginal bleeding or discharge.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Serum luteinizing hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, and estradiol levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

GnRH analog therapy is used for central precocious puberty with multiple secondary sexual characteristics and accelerated growth. This child has isolated breast enlargement, likely due to transient estrogen exposure, making GnRH analogs unwarranted.

B) CORRECT:

In young children, isolated breast development without other signs of pubertal progression, such as pubic or axillary hair, is often benign and termed premature thelarche. This condition is due to transient estrogen exposure, possibly from maternal hormones or increased breast tissue sensitivity. Monitoring the child over time is appropriate to ensure no additional secondary sexual characteristics develop, which would suggest true precocious puberty or other endocrine issues.

Key learning point: Premature thelarche, or premature breast development, is characterized by isolated breast enlargement in young girls without other signs of puberty.

C) INCORRECT:

An abdominal CT scan is reserved for suspected estrogen-producing neoplasms, which present with rapid symptom progression and additional features. The absence of such findings in this child makes a CT scan unnecessary, especially given the radiation exposure risk.

D) INCORRECT:

Hormonal evaluation is less informative in a 14-month-old with isolated breast enlargement and no other pubertal signs. Transient maternal estrogen exposure or mini-puberty can cause benign breast tissue changes. Hormone levels vary widely in infancy, making interpretation challenging and potentially misleading.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old girl is brought to the Outpatient Clinic by her mother for a well-child visit. Her mother is unsure whether her development is normal for her age. Examination shows a small mound of breast tissue elevating the papilla with a widened areola, and a few slightly pigmented, straight pubic hairs mainly along the labia. She has no axillary hair, and menarche has not occurred. She reports occasional mild breast tenderness.
Which of the following Tanner stages is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tanner stage I is a prepubertal stage with no glandular breast tissue or pubic hair development. The presence of a small mound of breast tissue and slightly pigmented pubic hairs indicates the onset of puberty, inconsistent with Tanner stage I.

B) INCORRECT:

Tanner stage III involves further breast enlargement beyond the areola and more abundant, darker, and coarser pubic hair. The described findings of a small breast mound and sparse, lightly pigmented pubic hair align with Tanner stage II, not stage III.

C) CORRECT:

Tanner stage II in females is characterized by the onset of breast budding, where a small mound of breast tissue elevates the papilla with a widened areola. This stage also includes the appearance of a few slightly pigmented, straight pubic hairs along the labia, indicating early pubarche. These changes mark the transition from prepubertal (Tanner stage I) to early puberty, driven by increasing estrogen levels that stimulate breast development and adrenal androgens that initiate pubic hair growth. The absence of axillary hair and menarche further supports Tanner stage II classification, as these features develop in later stages.

Key learning point: Tanner stage II is characterized by breast bud development and sparse pubic hair growth, which does not extend onto the mons pubis.

D) INCORRECT:

Tanner stage IV features pronounced breast development with a secondary mound and coarse, curly pubic hair, often with axillary hair. The findings of a small breast mound and sparse pubic hair are not consistent with stage IV.

questions.text: You are seeing a 9-year-old girl brought to your clinic by her parents, who are concerned about recent physical changes. She has started wearing a bra and uses a facial scrub for oily skin. Her parents have noticed increased body odor. She has a history of migraine headaches, which are controlled with propranolol. There is no family history of serious illness. She is at the 55th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is separation of the areola and breast contours, with the nipple and areola forming a secondary mound. She has coarse, dark axillary hair and sparse pubic hair. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Normal puberty typically begins between the ages of 8–13 years in girls and 9–14 years in boys. While the age of pubertal onset varies, the order of changes that occur is consistent: adrenarche, gonadarche, thelarche in girls, pubarche, growth spurt, and, lastly, menarche in girls or androgenic hair growth in boys. In girls, adrenarche usually goes unnoticed but may manifest with axillary and pubic hair growth. Thelarche is often the first visible sign of puberty, followed by pubarche as also seen in this patient. The development of secondary sexual characteristics during puberty is described by the Tanner stages. This girl's sparse (straight or curled) pubic hair is equivalent to stage Ph2 and her breast development corresponds to stage B4. If this patient continued to develop normally, her current symptoms would be followed by a growth spurt around age 11 and menarche approximately two years after the onset of puberty.

Studies suggest that in developed countries children are entering puberty at a younger age than before. This finding is especially pronounced in children with obesity, African American children, and Hispanic children.

Key learning point: The development of secondary sexual characteristics in girls between ages 8 and 13, following a predictable sequence, is a normal part of physiological puberty.

B) INCORRECT:

A functioning follicular ovarian cyst is the most common cause of precocious pseudopuberty in girls. They may be asymptomatic or manifest with abdominal pain or acute ovarian torsion. However, in girls, precocious puberty is defined as the development of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years. There is no reason to suspect an ovarian cyst in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of 21-hydroxylase is the most common cause of congenital adrenal hyperplasia and a potential cause of peripheral precocious puberty. Patients with congenital adrenal hyperplasia can present with precocious puberty due to the increased production of adrenal androgens. However, depending on the severity of the disease, female patients can also present with ambiguous genitalia and virilization due to excess androgens. Additionally, hypoglycemia and hypotension due to hypocortisolism and hypoaldosteronism are often present, none of which are seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Intracranial neoplasms such as tumors of the pineal gland can cause central precocious puberty due to premature activation of GnRH release and subsequent FSH and LH secretion. While a history of headaches may indicate an intracranial tumor, other symptoms of pineal gland tumors such as visual disturbances are not seen in this patient. Even more importantly, in girls, precocious puberty would manifest with the development of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years.

E) INCORRECT:

Tumors of the hypothalamic region (e.g., hamartomas) can cause central precocious puberty by prematurely activating the hypothalamo-hypophyseal axis, which is followed by the secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus. This patient has a history of headaches, which can be a sign of an intracranial tumor. However, in girls, precocious puberty would manifest with the development of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years.
questions.hint: The patient is likely going to experience a growth spurt and thickening of pubic hair soon, followed by the onset of intermittent vaginal bleeding over the next couple of years.

questions.text: A previously healthy 6-year-old boy is brought to your clinic because of increased facial and axillary hair. There is no family history of serious illness. His height and weight are at the 95th percentile. On examination, he has coarse pubic and axillary hair, and both the penis and left testicle are enlarged. Serum concentrations of human chorionic gonadotropin and alpha-fetoprotein are within the reference range. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Teratomas are more common in children and can manifest with a painless testicular mass and typically normal alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels. However, they usually do not secrete hormones and thus do not cause precocious puberty.

B) INCORRECT:

Seminomas can manifest with a painless testicular mass and normal alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels. However, these tumors have a peak incidence in the fourth decade of life and do not cause precocious puberty.

C) INCORRECT:

Sertoli cell tumors can manifest with a painless testicular mass and normal alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels. However, these tumors are more common in older males (with a peak incidence of around 40 years). Furthermore, although Sertoli cell tumors can also produce hormones, they more commonly secrete estrogen so that gynecomastia, rather than virilization is seen.

D) CORRECT:

Leydig cell tumors are rare testicular tumors that usually develop after the age of 4. The tumors typically manifest as painless testicular masses and produce large amounts of testosterone as well as smaller amounts of estrogen, progesterone, and corticosteroids. The excess in androgens leads to precocious pseudopuberty in boys with prominent external genitalia, accelerated skeletomuscular development, mature masculine voice, and growth of facial, axillary, and pubic hair. GnRH, FSH, and LH levels are decreased in response to the elevated androgen levels in precocious pseudopuberty. The treatment of Leydig-cell tumors consists of surgical resection using radical inguinal orchiectomy.

See “Overview of testicular tumors” table.

Key learning point: Leydig cell tumors in children secrete excess androgens, leading to precocious pseudopuberty with virilization and a painless testicular mass.

E) INCORRECT:

Choriocarcinoma can also present as a painless testicular mass and cause precocious puberty if it occurs in young children such as in this patient. However, human chorionic gonadotropin levels are usually markedly increased (which causes precocious puberty secondary to increased production of testosterone).
questions.hint: Laboratory studies in this patient would likely show elevated testosterone and estrogen levels.

questions.text: You are seeing a 6-year-old girl in your clinic for a well-child examination. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. Her height and weight are both at the 90th percentile. Vital signs are normal. On examination, she has enlarged breast buds extending beyond the areola and coarse pubic hair that does not extend onto the inner thigh. The rest of the examination is normal. An x-ray of her left hand shows a bone age of 10 years. After GnRH agonist stimulation, her serum luteinizing hormone levels increase to twice the median. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next best step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up in 3–6 months would be indicated for patients with suspected precocious puberty but a bone age that matches the chronological age. This patient has a bone age that is more than 1 year older than the chronological age. A different step is required to diagnose the cause of precocious puberty so that early treatment can be initiated to prevent short stature caused by early epiphyseal closure.

B) INCORRECT:

Leuprolide is the treatment of choice for CPP since it centrally suppresses both testosterone and estradiol production. However, a different step must be performed to rule out organic causes of CPP before therapy can be initiated.

C) INCORRECT:

An ultrasound of the pelvis is performed to screen for ovarian tumors or cysts, which can result in precocious puberty due to peripheral secretion of estrogen and/or androgens. However, patients with peripheral precocious puberty would have normal or only mildly increased levels of LH following the administration of a GnRH agonist.

D) CORRECT:

An MRI of the brain is indicated to rule out intracranial causative pathologies of CPP. Organic causes of CPP include hypothalamic hamartomas, hydrocephalus, pineal tumors, and intracranial infections (e.g., tuberculous meningitis). Treatment with leuprolide to suppress both testosterone and estradiol production can be initiated after the MRI has been performed. Further steps of management depend on the underlying cause (e.g., tumor excision).

Key learning point: In central precocious puberty, a brain MRI is required to rule out intracranial lesions before starting treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

In a female patient with precocious puberty, serum dehydroepiandrosterone levels can be measured to rule out hyperandrogenism (e.g., as a result of adrenocortical tumors, virilizing ovarian tumors, congenital adrenal hyperplasia, exogenous androgen administration). Although this patient has precocious puberty, hyperandrogenism causes GnRH-independent, peripheral precocious puberty, which is characterized by a lack of increase in serum LH levels following GnRH agonist administration. Moreover, this patient does not have virilizing features such as hirsutism, or clitoromegaly to suggest hyperandrogenism. This patient has CPP, for which a different step is indicated.
questions.hint: Early secondary sexual development with advanced bone age in a 6-year-old girl is indicative of precocious puberty. Elevation of serum LH levels after stimulation with a GnRH agonist indicates central precocious puberty (CPP).

questions.text: You are seeing a 7-year-old girl brought to your clinic by her parents for evaluation of pubic hair development. She has a history of fractures in both legs and her right arm. Her school performance is good. There is no family history of serious illness, and she takes no medications. Vital signs are normal. On genital examination, she has coarse, dark hair along the labia. Her breast glands are enlarged, and the breast buds extend beyond the areolar diameter. Several hyperpigmented macules with rough, serpiginous borders of varying sizes are present on the right lower and upper extremities. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tuberous sclerosis can manifest with café au lait spots. However, the condition typically manifests along with ash-leaf spots, adenoma sebaceum, Shagreen patches, retinal lesions, cardiac rhabdomyomas, infantile seizures, developmental delay, and intellectual impairment, none of which are seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

In select types of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), patients may present with precocious puberty due to errors in steroidogenesis. Patients with CAH also have an increased risk of osteoporosis and pathological fractures due to the need for lifelong glucocorticoid-replacement therapy. However, café au lait spots are not a feature of CAH. Furthermore, other typical features of CAH, such as hypotension and severe electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., hyponatremia, hypochloremia, hyperkalemia), caused by decreased production of aldosterone and cortisol, are absent in this patient. Lastly, if left untreated, CAH can lead to prenatal virilization in girls, which would likely be detected at birth; screening for CAH is currently recommended for all neonates.

C) INCORRECT:

Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) manifests with recurrent bone fractures due to osteopenia. However, precocious puberty and café au lait spots are not commonly seen in OI. Furthermore, this patient lacks further findings of OI such as blue sclerae, growth retardation, hearing loss, and brittle, opalescent teeth.

D) INCORRECT:

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) can manifest with café au lait spots and skeletal abnormalities (e.g., fractures, bowing of long bones). However, this patient lacks further typical findings of NF1 such as neurofibromas, optic glioma, Lisch nodules, or a family history of NF1 in a first-degree relative. While pathological fractures in NF1 are caused by cortical thinning of long bones, fractures in this patient's condition result from fibrous dysplasia.

E) CORRECT:

The triad of pathological fractures, café au lait spots, and precocious puberty is highly suggestive of McCune-Albright syndrome. Pathological fractures result from polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, which generally manifests with well-defined, lobulated lesions with a thin cortex and a radiolucent ground-glass appearance on x-ray of the long bones. Laboratory studies typically show elevated alkaline phosphatase along with normal calcium, PTH, and 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels. In McCune-Albright syndrome, precocious puberty is most commonly seen in girls; it is caused by excess estrogen production in girls and testosterone in boys (peripheral precocity). Treatment is symptomatic and includes surgery for pathological fractures and the administration of bisphosphonates. The medical management of precocious puberty consists of estrogen synthesis blockers (e.g., ketoconazole, testolactone) or selective estrogen receptor modulators (e.g., tamoxifen) in girls and antiandrogens in combination with aromatase inhibitors in boys.

Key learning point: McCune-Albright syndrome is characterized by the triad of precocious puberty, café au lait spots with irregular borders, and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia leading to pathological fractures.
Image Description:

There is a flat, hyperpigmented, irregularly shaped macule visible on the patient's forearm. These macules are also known as “café-au-lait spots.”

Unilateral café-au-lait spots in patients with precocious onset of puberty suggest McCune-Albright syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient has a history of several bone fractures and presents with signs of precocious puberty and café au lait spots. These features are associated with a specific medical condition.

questions.text: You are seeing a 7-year-old girl in your clinic for a well-child examination. Her mother reports that she had her first menstrual period 1 week ago. She has no history of serious illness, and her immunizations are up-to-date. On examination, she has Tanner stage 3 breast development and pubic hair. Without treatment, as an adult, this patient is at greatest risk for which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infertility can be caused by several endocrine conditions that result in hypogonadism, including Kallmann syndrome and prolactinoma. Patients with untreated precocious puberty do not usually have an increased risk of infertility in adulthood.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients who have decreased levels of estrogen (e.g., postmenopausal women) have increased bone resorption, which increases the risk of developing osteoporosis. In contrast, patients with untreated precocious puberty experience a premature increase in sex hormone levels and do not have a greater risk of developing osteoporosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Delayed skeletal maturity can be caused by Laron syndrome, an endocrine disorder characterized by decreased growth due to a defect of growth hormone receptors. Patients with untreated precocious puberty experience premature, not delayed, skeletal maturity as a result of increased estrogen levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Coarse facial features can be caused by exposure to excess growth hormone (e.g., from a pituitary adenoma). If this exposure occurs during childhood (before epiphyseal plate closure) and remains untreated, it results in pituitary gigantism. Coarse facial features are not seen in patients with untreated precocious puberty.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with precocious puberty have an increased risk for short stature as an adult. Although increased levels of sex hormones initially cause accelerated growth, they also trigger early epiphyseal plate closure. As a result, patients have an increased height velocity but decreased adolescent/adult height. Central precocious puberty is caused by increased gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion. This excess secretion is typically idiopathic but can also be caused by tumors (e.g., hamartomas, astrocytomas, pinealomas). Peripheral precocious puberty is caused by GnRH-independent exposure to sex hormones, which can be caused by granulosa cell tumors, Leydig cell tumors, congenital adrenal hyperplasia, and McCune-Albright syndrome.

Key learning point: Precocious puberty leads to early epiphyseal plate closure, increasing the risk of short adult stature despite initially rapid growth.
questions.hint: This patient has precocious puberty, a condition characterized by the development of secondary sexual characteristics (e.g., thelarche, menarche) before 8 years of age in girls and 9 years of age in boys.

questions.text: You are seeing a 9-year-old boy brought to your clinic by his parents, who are concerned about early physical changes related to puberty. He is about to turn 10 years old in 2 months. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His immunizations are up to date. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 99th percentile for weight. Vital signs are normal. On examination, he is Tanner stage 2 for pubic hair and Tanner stage 3 for genital development, with sparse, soft axillary hair. Which one of the following actions is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The measurement of serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels is usually performed in children when there is a suspicion of nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). However, nonclassic CAH is associated with precocious pubarche with delayed testicular enlargement, which is due to the adrenal source of precocity. This patient's pubic hair and genitals are developing in accordance with the normal sequence; he is at Tanner stage 2 for pubic hair development and Tanner stage 3 for genital development. Moreover, at 9 years old, this patient's changes would not be considered precocious, making nonclassic CAH unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

The GnRH stimulation test is used to differentiate between central and peripheral precocious puberty in cases in which LH is decreased or equivocal. However, while this 9-year-old boy is experiencing the physical changes of puberty earlier than his older siblings, he is within the normal age of onset of puberty for boys. Therefore, a GnRH stimulation test is not needed.

C) INCORRECT:

Serum testosterone levels should be measured in patients with suspected peripheral precocious puberty to further evaluate the underlying cause. Patients with excess testosterone production may present with precocious puberty. However, even though this patient is experiencing physical changes of puberty earlier than his older siblings, he is within the normal age of onset for boys. Therefore, there is no indication for measuring serum testosterone levels.

D) CORRECT:

Reassurance is the best next step in management, as this 9-year-old boy's physical examination shows typical signs of the onset of puberty. Children do not start puberty at the same age, and, while he is developing earlier than his siblings, he is still within the normal distribution. Additionally, this patient is following the normal sequence of development (adrenarche, gonadarche, thelarche in girls, pubarche, growth spurt, and, lastly, menarche in girls or androgenic hair growth in boys) with Tanner stage 3 for genital development and Tanner stage 2 for pubic hair development. His height is in the 97th percentile and weight is in the 99th percentile, indicating that he has hit the pubertal growth spurt.

Precocious puberty should be suspected if secondary sex characteristics (e.g., testicular enlargement in males) appear before the age of 9 years in boys or 8 years in girls.

Key learning point: Pubertal changes in boys beginning at age 9 or older are within the normal range and typically require only reassurance if development follows the expected sequence.

E) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the brain should be performed as part of the workup in patients with suspected central precocious puberty (CPP), as central nervous system (CNS) lesions are a common cause of CPP. Hamartomas in the hypothalamus are the most common type of CNS lesion associated with CPP in very young children; however, other symptoms, such as seizures, would be expected. Additionally, while this patient's physical changes started earlier than in his older siblings, he is within the normal age of onset of puberty for boys.
questions.hint: The normal age of onset of puberty is 9–14 years in boys and 8–13 years in girls.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to your clinic for evaluation of short stature. She was born at term with a normal birth length. She has not yet had menarche. Her mother is 162 cm tall and her father is 177 cm tall. She is at the 3rd percentile for height and the 40th percentile for weight. Vital signs are normal. Breast and pubic hair development are Tanner stage 2. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: X-ray of the hand and wrist.
Measurement of serum LH, FSH, and testosterone concentrations.
Measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor concentration.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Genetic karyotyping can be used to diagnose chromosomal abnormalities such as Turner syndrome. While patients with Turner syndrome also have a female phenotype, short stature, and delayed puberty, other characteristic signs of the condition are absent in this patient (e.g., a webbed neck, shield chest, cardiac and renal malformations). Furthermore, although Turner syndrome cannot be completely ruled out in this patient, the condition is rare, and more common causes of short stature should be excluded first.

B) CORRECT:

An x-ray of the left hand and wrist is commonly used to determine bone age and should be performed in almost all children with short stature to determine whether their growth is delayed or accelerated (e.g., by precocious puberty). Additional testing (e.g., celiac serology, thyroid function tests, serum IGF-1) is not routinely required and only warranted if the child is extremely short (< 0.6th percentile) or if the history and physical examination are consistent with a specific disorder.

This patient was of normal length at birth, and both parents are of normal size, which suggests a constitutional growth delay. Patients with constitutional growth delay typically have a delayed bone age and, after a brief downward shift in percentiles after birth, a constant growth rate at or below the 3rd percentile during childhood. Patients with constitutional growth delay present with short stature during childhood, but their delayed bone age is associated with a longer period of growth, with most ultimately reaching their adult target height. Patients and their families should be reassured, but growth and development should be monitored nonetheless to rule out any pathologies.

Key learning point: An x-ray of the hand and wrist to assess bone age is the key initial diagnostic test for evaluating short stature and suspected constitutional growth delay in children.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with short stature, neuroimaging is only indicated if the diagnosis of growth hormone deficiency has been established or if there are additional risk factors for an intracranial neoplasm (e.g., history of cranial irradiation).

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of sex hormones (LH, FSH, estradiol/testosterone) is useful in the differential diagnosis of delayed puberty and/or primary amenorrhea if an underlying chronic disease or hormonal abnormality is suspected. However, there are no abnormalities in this patient aside from her short stature. Although she has not reached menarche at the age of 14, the development of secondary sex characteristics (i.e., breast and pubic hair development at Tanner stage 2) suggests another diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) levels are measured to evaluate patients with short stature for growth hormone (GH) deficiency. While patients with congenital GH deficiency usually also have a normal birth length, they are often already symptomatic in the neonatal period, with hypoglycemia and prolonged jaundice. In addition, IGF-1 levels should only be evaluated in patients with slow growth (e.g., downward deviation of growth curves, change in percentiles) or with extremely short stature (< 0.6th percentile).
questions.hint: Further questioning will likely reveal a family history of delayed growth. However, both parents are of normal height now.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to your clinic by her mother because she has not yet attained menarche. She has no history of serious illness. Her height and weight are at the 50th percentile. On examination, there is no glandular breast tissue and no pubic hair development. Pelvic examination is normal. The remainder of the examination is normal. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the brain is only indicated if FSH levels are low and a hypothalamic or pituitary disease (e.g., pituitary tumor) is suspected, which could cause hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and subsequent primary amenorrhea. This patient does not present with additional symptoms of a process in the sella region, such as headaches, vision changes, or any other signs of hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction.

B) INCORRECT:

The GnRH stimulation test is the gold standard for identifying central precocious puberty. This patient lacks signs of puberty such as menarche and breast development and requires further evaluation of primary amenorrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

The progesterone challenge test is indicated in suspected gonadotropin deficiency (low FSH, LH, and estrogen). Gonadotropin levels of this patient have not been measured yet, therefore, another step is more appropriate at this point.

D) CORRECT:

The evaluation of primary amenorrhea starts with a pelvic examination and a pregnancy test to rule out pregnancy. If pelvic examination confirms the presence of a uterus, serum FSH level should be assessed. A high serum FSH level indicates gonadal dysgenesis, most commonly due to chromosomal aberrations, e.g., in Turner syndrome (45,XO). Causes of a low serum FSH level include constitutional growth delay, functional growth delay (e.g., due to inflammatory bowel disease or chronic kidney disease), and hypothalamic-pituitary disorders (e.g., hemochromatosis, injury, Kallmann syndrome). Further testing depends on the suspected etiology and includes serum TSH and prolactin levels to rule out uncommon causes of primary amenorrhea (e.g., hyperprolactinemia due to prolactinoma, hypothyroidism).

In patients with blind or absent vagina on pelvic examination, a pelvic ultrasound should be performed to visualize internal reproductive organs. Congenital reproductive outflow tract obstruction (e.g., imperforate hymen) should be considered if a uterus is present. In patients without a uterus on ultrasound, serum testosterone levels and karyotyping are used to determine the underlying pathology (e.g., Mullerian agenesis, androgen insensitivity syndrome).

Key learning point: In primary amenorrhea with absent secondary sexual characteristics and a normal uterus, the initial evaluation should include measurement of serum FSH to distinguish between gonadal and central causes.

Depending on the result of the serum FSH studies, the working diagnosis for this patient could be either gonadal dysgenesis (e.g., Swyer syndrome) or a hypothalamic-pituitary disorder (e.g., normosmic isolated GnRH deficiency). Functional or constitutional growth delays are unlikely as the patient is in the 50th percentile for weight and height.

E) INCORRECT:

All patients who have not reached menarche by the age of 16 years or have not developed secondary sexual characteristics (breasts, pubic hair) by the age of 13 years must be evaluated for primary amenorrhea. Further tests should be initiated to identify correctable causes and initiate treatment, if necessary.
questions.hint: Absent or incomplete development of secondary sexual characteristics by the age of 14 years in boys or 13 years in girls indicates delayed puberty. This delay can be constitutional, secondary to underlying conditions, or due to hypogonadism.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is concerned about delayed physical changes compared with classmates. He has no medical history. Which clinical sign marks the earliest stage of pubertal development in boys?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pubic hair growth, or pubarche, is influenced by adrenal androgens and typically occurs after the initial activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. In boys, pubertal onset is first indicated by testicular enlargement, preceding the development of secondary sexual characteristics like pubic hair.

B) CORRECT:

The earliest stage of male puberty is marked by the activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, leading to increased secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). This stimulates the release of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), which act on the testes. FSH promotes Sertoli cell proliferation and initiates inhibin B production, resulting in increased testicular volume. An increase in testicular volume to greater than 4 mL signifies Tanner Stage 2, the earliest physical sign of puberty in boys. Subsequent changes, such as pubic hair development and increased penile length, occur later.

Key learning point: The earliest physical sign of puberty in boys is an increase in testicular size.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased penile length is a characteristic change during puberty but does not occur at its onset. Puberty begins with the reactivation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, leading to testicular enlargement before noticeable penile growth.

D) INCORRECT:

Darkening of the scrotal skin occurs as puberty progresses but follows the initial increase in testicular volume. This pigmentation change is a secondary effect of androgen exposure and occurs after the activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis.
